aboutYou.title: About you
questions: Which department do you work for?
Does your department have a data strategy?

dataCulture.title: Data Culture
dataCulture.question: Which statement best describes the culture in your organization when working with data?
choices:
Data is as an vague term which causes insecurities.
No employees with significant data backgrounds work here.

Data is an interesting concept that brings great benefits. There are uncertainties about when to use data and what to expect. Employees with some data analytics knowledge work in specialist positions.

Data is understood to be an enabler for progress and a support for existing and planned activities. Higher management and specialized positions are fully aware of the need to collect, store and act on data. Data analysis is recognized as a needed skill.

Psychological barriers to access data have been removed and comfort around data is promoted. Insights from data analysis are used and optimized at all levels of the workflow. Data literacy is an important skill for most employees, even at a senior level. There are resources (time, budget, human resources) dedicated for data handling and conversion.

dataEthicsAndSecurity.title: Data Ethics and Security
dataEthicsAndSecurity.question: Which statement best describes your organization's take on data ethics and security?
choices: I am not sure how data is handled in my organization. No guidelines are defined that ensure confidentiality, integrity and availability of data.

Some employees and projects are aware of potential security issues and uncoordinated attempts are made to handle data securely.  There is rising awareness of the importance of responsible use of data, but no defined guidelines
Data protection guidelines are defined and employees know how to share data responsibly. Organization-wide policies for secure and ethically sound data handling exist.

Consistent, organization-wide policies for secure and ethically sound data handling are constantly redefined and updated. Senior employees are responsible for the enforcement of these rules. Processes are in place to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data.

askQuestions.title: Ask Questions to Collect Data
askQuestions.question: How would you describe your ability to formulate questions to get meaningful insights from data?
choices: I have no idea what questions can be answered by data.
I am able to formulate questions that can be answered with simple data queries.
I develop projects based on questions that need complex data queries and multiple iterations to resolve.
My projects are based on multidimensional questions that need complex data queries and answer all main questions and sub-questions. No single person can handle these inquiries.

find.title: Finding Data
find.question: Which data sources / strategies do you use in order to find data?
choices: I use basic search engines to try to find data.
I know where to find a few data sources and perform advanced use of search engines to locate them.
I have a broad understanding of different data sources and can choose the most relevant ones to help me with my work. I am aware of and use open data portals for specific topics.

I have a solid understanding of the various possible types of data sources. I create assessment criteria for selecting the ones most relevant to my business needs. I can detect when a given problem or need cannot be solved with the existing data, and know how to deploy research techniques to obtain new data (e.g. complex queries).

get.title: Gathering Data
get.question: Which strategies do you use in order to gather data?
choices: I gather data through surveys and forms in full text and use it as base for further analysis.
I use often make use of internal programs to access data (e.g. Excel) and downloads of data formats such as .csv
I access data using complex data formats (e.g. JSON, XML). I can use APIs to get data.

I access data through programming and other sophisticated methods (e.g. automated data scrapers / scripts). I can convert input format into a form that can be used for further processing and analysis.

verify.title: Verifying Data
verify.question: How do you assess the quality of your data sources?
choices: I do not know how to evaluate the quality of data. I take data sources at face value.
I can verify the accuracy and completeness of simple data sources
I can perform multiple layers of data verification and follow standard procedures that are implemented across the organization.
I can do a data quality assessment independently where data evaluation criteria regarding authorship, method of obtaining and analyzing data, comparability and quality are precisely defined.

clean.title: Cleaning Data
clean.question: Which strategies do you use to clean your data?
choices: I did not know that data might have to be checked, cleaned or normalized. I use data as is.
I know that data is not perfect. I am awareness of some data quality criteria (e.g. empty fields, duplicates) and can manually fix errors.

I detect and remove invalid records using programs that support data cleaning (e.g. OpenRefine). I am very aware of data quality criteria (e.g. machine processable, empty fields, duplicate detection).

I am able to remove invalid records and translate all the columns to use a same set of values through an automated script. I often combine different datasets into a single table, remove duplicate entries or apply any number of other normalizations.

analyze.title: Analyze Data
analyze.question: How do you analyze your data?
choices: I create simple data tables and basic summaries of data. I often use bar and pie charts.
I work with basic descriptive statistics and leverage pivot tables for aggregating information. I often use histograms and boxplots.
I can work with advanced statistics and create inferential views of data, linear regressions and decision trees.
I am able to use a full suite of machine learning tools (e.g. clustering, forecasting, boosting, ensemble learning) to analyze data.

visualize.title: Visualize Data
visualize.question: Which strategy do you use to visualize your data?
choices: I donâ€™t know how to present data. I choose standard visualizations based on what looks best (trial and error).
I can visualize specific information that can easily be represented (e.g. 2 variable using Excel).
I create interactive charts / dashboards using visual analytics tools (e.g. Tableau). I am able to visualize the uncertainties along with the data (range of values).
I can create sophisticated visualizations and dashboards that are linked to data and anticipate users needs.

communicate.title: Communicating with Data
communicate.question: How do you communicate your data outputs?
choices: I do not know how to communicate my data findings or how to put them into a broader context.
I have a limited ability to use data outputs. I use simple narratives to  support static visualizations / key numbers (e.g. operational reports).
My work is supported by interactive visualizations and a sophisticated narrative to put my insights in a broader context. (e.g. data storytelling)

I can synthesize and communicate data outputs in a variety of ways. I base my communication on the nature of the data, it's purpose and the audience (e.g. data storytelling, data-driven campaigning, reproducable research).

assessAndInterpret.title: Assessing & Interpreting Data Outputs
assessAndInterpret.question: Assessing & Interpreting Data Outputs
choices: I take reports and visualizations at face value without questioning their correctness and message.
I have heard about 'fake news'. I know I need to critically assess data outputs and interpret the results but  I am still unsure of what I need to look for to evaluate them
I know how to evaluate data outputs and can interpret the results confidently and critically.
I consistently question and challenge data outputs and results. I can interpet and translate insights into actionable knowledge.
